mCode

Terminology

Toolkit

mCode in Libraries

We hope mCode will help librarians situate data services within their organizational context. Currently, most public libraries have limited data-related services that extend beyond the internal use of data to evaluate the use of resources and the impact of library programming. At the core of this model are values underpinning the work of public libraries, and the communities served are the bounds. Each layer of the model connects with and influences the next.

mCode: Model for Community Open Data Engagement

Values

Our professional core values of access, equity, intellectual freedom, supporting the public good, and sustainability connect with the ethics that have supported the development of the open data movement, particularly accountability and transparency in the public sphere. These both connect to the UN Sustainable Development goals, which are tied to change at the local level, where public libraries have the most impact on national agendas. Libraries must respond to societal changes, but the path to integrating that response into existing library services is not always clear. Take, for example, the integration of social services with library services to address the needs of library users in crisis; at this point, various models have emerged depending on the library's community, organizational structure, and culture.

Internal Capacity

If your library's values align with using data for decision-making, meeting community needs, and strategic planning, you already have some internal capacity to work with data. Libraries use data to assess their community's return on investment in them for the services they provide. Many public library websites provide calculators to illustrate this return on investment publicly and internally; this data is used to evaluate and improve collections and programs to meet the needs of their communities. Further, libraries will use data about their communities to evaluate and improve the collections and programs offered. Depending on how broadly data is used within an organization, this will often limit the extent to which data use extends to the outer reaches of the model. If the capacity for working with data rests in the hands of only a few staff members, then the potential for doing more with data is limited. If there is one person primarily responsible for collecting and analyzing data within the library, then the reach of data services will be limited. Internal capacity is critical to expanding the impact of data services in public libraries.

Data Access

How a library makes data accessible and to whom will depend on its internal capacity in terms of human resources and technology infrastructure. Some libraries make internal library data and community data widely accessible throughout the organization, encouraging library staff to utilize data in their work. For example, libraries create data dashboards utilizing homegrown tools or products like Power BI or Tableau. Additionally, making data accessible for analysis or use over the long term will require some level of professional expertise and technological support.

Data access can mean that public and collection service staff provide access to published data sources and can aid in using those sources. The kinds of data literacy and data analysis skills available to library users vary greatly depending on the library staff's expertise. There is no uniform expectation that public libraries or public librarians will provide access to data resources, tools, and assistance in using them.

Beyond service at an information desk, providing access to data to constituents external to the library can require community partnership, particularly if their data is being shared. For example, a partnership is a good idea if your library shares data collected by a local agency, such as crime data. You don't want to misrepresent the work of community agencies or appear to be critical or political in your sharing of their data. Typically, a more robust technical infrastructure will be needed to provide access to datasets and data analysis tools. MOUs, governance structures, data collection development policy are likely to be in place to guide this work. When public libraries provide access to local data, often a partnership is struck with the city government to support access to financial and technical resources, as well as buy-in from local agencies who might be hesitant to provide their own data to support open government through open access to data.

Programming & Instruction

With access to any of the three kinds described above (internal, published data sources, or external), programming and instruction involving and around data are now possible. Audiences for the programming and instruction can be both internal and external. For example, internal access to library use data and data representing community characteristics can provide opportunities for in-service professional development aimed at either informing staff about decisions being made because of the data or teaching them to use it to meet the needs of the particular communities they serve.

Programming and instruction related to data can be provided to library users just as with any other areas for programming and instruction. Sometimes, the library takes the lead when it comes to such services. For example, librarians will often take the lead regarding instruction related to using subscription databases or summer reading programs. Whereas community partners are more likely to take the lead when it comes to English as a second language instruction and public safety programming. With data depending on the topic and the context, either library staff or community partners can take the lead. We have found that programming and instruction efforts related to data are most successful when collaboration between the library and community groups or agencies takes place.

Community Context

For this reason, the community context is most closely connected to the programming and instruction aspect of the model, even though it envelops the whole of the library's role in this space. Programming is where relevancy is most keenly felt. For example, the local government aligned workforce development to data skills in one community. It supported the public library's early efforts to engage the community in using data to address local issues. Meanwhile, in another community, which is more affluent and highly educated in terms of its demographics, programming or instruction related to data could not gain traction.
